title: Karl Paul von Quosdanovich
text:
Karl Paul von Quosdanovich (, in some sources also "Quasdanovich" or "Guosdanovich"; 1763 – 5 February 1817) was a <a href="Croatia">Croatia</a>n nobleman and general in the <a href="Habsburg%20Monarchy">Habsburg Monarchy</a> imperial army service.was a <a href="Habsburg%20Monarchy">Habsburg</a> nobleman and general. He achieved the rank of <a href="major%20general">major general</a> and was awarded the Knight's Cross of the <a href="Military%20Order%20of%20Maria%20Theresa">Military Order of Maria Theresa</a> in 1801 and the Commander's Cross of the same <a href="Order%20%28decoration%29">order of merit</a> in 1814.
Biography.
Baron Karl Paul von Quosdanovich was born in <a href="Brezovac%20%C5%BDumbera%C4%8Dki">Brezovac Žumberački</a> near <a href="Samobor">Samobor</a> (at the time in the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Croatia%20%28Habsburg%29">Kingdom of Croatia within Habsburg Monarchy</a>), which is in <a href="%C5%BDumberak">Žumberak</a>, a range of <a href="mountains">mountains</a> between <a href="Croatia">Croatia</a> and <a href="Slovenia">Slovenia</a>, known for his <a href="uskoks">uskoks</a>, the <a href="refugee">refugee</a>s from parts of Croatia occupied by the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> and traditional <a href="guerrilla">guerrilla</a> soldiers. The Gvozdanović family surname dates back to <a href="Ra%C5%A1ka%20%28region%29">Raška</a> and <a href="Zeta%20%28medieval%20region%29">Zeta</a> in the Middle Ages. He was a relative of <a href="Petar%20Vid%20Gvozdanovi%C4%87">Petar Vid Gvozdanović</a>, <a href="Lieutenant%20field%20marshal">Fieldmarshal Lieutenant</a>, who distinguished himself in the <a href="War%20of%20the%20Bavarian%20Succession">War of the Bavarian Succession</a> (1778–1779) and the <a href="War%20of%20the%20First%20Coalition">War of the First Coalition</a> (1792–1797).
Having started his military career as a young man, he was promoted gradually, becoming <a href="Captain%20%28armed%20forces%29">captain</a> in 1796, <a href="major">major</a> in 1801, <a href="colonel">colonel</a> in 1809, and finally <a href="major%20general">major general</a> on 12 May 1813. He fought in many battles during several wars at the end of the 18th and the beginning of the 19th century (<a href="Austro%E2%80%93Turkish%20War%20%281787%E2%80%931791%29">Austro–Turkish War (1787–1791)</a>, <a href="French%20Revolutionary%20Wars">French Revolutionary Wars</a>, <a href="Napoleonic%20Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a>). For his merits he was awarded the <a href="Knight%27s%20Cross">Knight's Cross</a> of the <a href="Order%20of%20Maria%20Theresa">Order of Maria Theresa</a> in the 66th promotion ceremony which took place on 18 August 1801, as well as the Commander's Cross on 8 March 1814.
Quosdanovich died at the beginning of 1817 in <a href="Pan%C4%8Devo">Pančevo</a>, a town in <a href="Banat%20Military%20Frontier">Banat Military Frontier</a> of the <a href="Habsburg%20Monarchy">Habsburg Monarchy</a> (now <a href="Serbia">Serbia</a>), at the age of 53.
